author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Kristalina Georgieva will remain managing director of the I.M.F., its board says.
description: An independent inquiry commissioned by the World Bank had concluded that she played a central role in manipulating data to placate China.
content: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund’s executive board on Monday expressed confidence in the leadership of Kristalina Georgieva, its managing director, after allegations that she manipulated data to placate China when she was a senior World Bank official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Paddy Moloney, Irish Piper Who Led the Chieftains, Dies at 83
description: The band he fronted for nearly 60 years toured the world, collaborated with rock stars and helped spark a renaissance for traditional Irish music.
content: Paddy Moloney, the playful but disciplined frontman and bagpiper of the Chieftains, a band that was at the forefront of the worldwide revival of traditional Irish music played with traditional instruments, died on Monday in Dublin. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberto Lovato
title: A Memoir of Filipino American Family Life in the Wake of Colonialism
description: “Concepcion,” by Albert Samaha, combines the epic sweep of global history with an intimate family narrative.
content: CONCEPCIONAn Immigrant Family’s FortunesBy Albert Samaha
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Feito
title: An Investigation Into a Virgin Birth Upends Lives in This Sly English Novel
description: “Small Pleasures,” by Clare Chambers, features the lone woman journalist at a 1950s suburban English newspaper, whose life is upended when she’s assigned to investigate an unusual story.
content: SMALL PLEASURESBy Clare Chambers
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Martin Sherwin, Prize-winning Biographer of Oppenheimer, Dies at 84
description: A historian of the nuclear age, he and his co-author, Kai Bird, won a 2006 Pulitzer for their book about the scientist behind the atom bomb.
content: Martin J. Sherwin, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer of J. Robert Oppenheimer, known as the father of the atom bomb, and a scholar who plumbed the history and impact of the nuclear age, died on Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Luke Vander Ploeg, Rachel Quester, Chelsea Daniel, Lisa Chow, Marc Georges, Patricia Willens, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Is Child Care a Public Responsibility?
description: Democrats believe the system is broken — and they have a proposal for fixing it.
content: Many Americans pay more for child care than they do for their mortgages, even though the wages for those who provide the care are among the lowest in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justices Seem Ready to Let Kentucky’s Attorney General Defend Abortion Law
description: After the state’s political landscape shifted in 2019, the Democratic governor and the Republican attorney general disagreed on defending the law.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments in an abortion case on Tuesday, but the issue for the justices was a procedural one: Could Kentucky’s attorney general, a Republican, defend a state abortion law when the governor, a Democrat, refused to pursue further appeals after a federal appeals court struck down the law?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: One Woman Won a Nobel This Year. Quotas Aren’t the Answer, an Official Says.
description: Only one of the 13 laureates this year was a woman, but the head of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences dismissed the idea of guaranteeing representation.
content: After a year in which only one out of 13 Nobel laureates was a woman, a top official at the institution that awards some of the prizes dismissed the idea of gender quotas, saying the current system was in line with “the spirit of Alfred Nobel’s last will.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Victoria Chang’s ‘Dear Memory’ Is a Multimedia Exploration of Grief
description: In her new book, Victoria Chang brings together letters, photos, marriage certificates, floor plans and other documents to examine memory and loss.
content: DEAR MEMORYLetters on Writing, Silence, and GriefBy Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The I.M.F. warns of inflation and a slowing recovery as it lowers its forecast.
description: The global growth forecast was pared to 5.9 percent from 6 percent because of the Delta variant and supply chain bottlenecks. The U.S. growth prediction was cut to 6 percent from 7 percent.
content: The global economic recovery is losing momentum as the resurgence of the coronavirus and widespread supply chain disruptions threaten to be a drag on a world economy that is trying to find its footing, the International Monetary Fund said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Large and Costly Battle to Contain a Megafire
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 12, 2021.
content: “Fifteen years ago, a 100,000-acre fire would be the largest fire of your career. Now, we have one-million-acre fires. We’re the size of Rhode Island, working toward Delaware.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Jimmy Neary, Whose Irish Pub Became a Power Brokers’ Hub, Dies at 91
description: Opening on St. Patrick’s Day, 1967, Neary’s attracted politicians, media players, archbishops and more, drawn as much by Mr. Neary himself as by the lamb chops.
content: Jimmy Neary, an Irish immigrant who boarded a ship to America in the 1950s and went on to open a namesake East Side pub and restaurant in Manhattan that for more than a half century has been a canteen for the city’s power brokers, died on Oct. 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candace Jackson
title: High-End Design Comes to the Fish Tank
description: Luxury home aquariums now can rival installations at public aquariums in size and scale, and they come with hefty price tags.
content: Stuck at home during the pandemic, many Americans took in dogs or cats. Others took up a more elaborate pet hobby: luxury home aquariums. Something of a cross between home décor, entertainment, wildlife and pet shelter, these custom aquariums can weigh more than 75,000 pounds and cost as much as $750,000 at the top end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Honestly, You Should Keep Using These Verboten Terms
description: The language police have gone too far.
content: To speak our language these days with enlightenment is to harbor an ongoing sense that there are words and expressions that come to mind but that, upon reflection, we shouldn’t utter. I refer not only to terms like the N-word — an easy case for self-censorship — but also to an eternally morphing assemblage of locutions that pedants, our kids, human resources and the Twitter herd say we shouldn’t use anymore. Terms that are hardly egregious but maybe just aren’t the best look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: Britain’s Covid Missteps Cost Thousands of Lives, Inquiry Finds
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s slowness last year to impose a lockdown and institute widespread testing had tragic results, according to a parliamentary report.
content: LONDON — Britain’s initial response to the Covid-19 pandemic “ranks as one of the most important public health failures the United Kingdom has ever experienced,” a parliamentary inquiry reported on Tuesday, blaming the government for “many thousands of deaths which could have been avoided.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Hochul Leads Democratic Field in First Major Poll of N.Y. Governor’s Race
description: A Marist College poll found that voters favored Gov. Kathy Hochul over potential primary rivals, including the state attorney general, Letitia James.
content: When Kathy Hochul unexpectedly became governor of New York two months ago, she was immediately faced with two challenges: Leading a state traversing a pandemic while simultaneously building a statewide campaign operation to run for a full term next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: In Review, F.D.A. Stays Neutral on the Need for a Moderna Booster
description: An advisory panel is to vote later this week on whether to recommend emergency authorization of boosters for the Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccines.
content: The Food and Drug Administration set the stage Tuesday for a new round of decisions on which Americans should get coronavirus booster shots, releasing a review of data suggesting that an additional half-dose of Moderna’s vaccine at least six months after the second dose increased antibody levels. But the agency did not take a position on whether an additional shot was necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: What the Future May Hold for the Coronavirus and Us
description: Viral evolution is a long game. Here’s where scientists think we could be headed.
content: On Jan. 9, 2020, about a week after the world first learned of a mysterious cluster of pneumonia cases in central China, authorities announced that scientists had found the culprit: a novel coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: A judge says New York must allow religious exemptions, for now, to its health care worker vaccine mandate.
description: The judge ruled that the state must allow the exemptions while a lawsuit challenging the mandate, brought by 17 health care workers, makes its way through the courts.
content: A federal judge ruled on Tuesday that New York State health officials must allow employers to grant religious exemptions to a Covid-19 vaccine mandate for health care workers while a lawsuit challenging the mandate makes its way through the courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Alan Rappeport
title: World’s Growth Cools and the Rich-Poor Divide Widens
description: The International Monetary Fund says the persistence of the coronavirus and global supply chain crisis weighs on economies.
content: As the world economy struggles to find its footing, the resurgence of the coronavirus and supply chain chokeholds threaten to hold back the global recovery’s momentum, a closely watched report warned on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Cause for a Correction
description: Conor Sefkow coins a neologism.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to today’s constructor, Conor Sefkow, for making his New York Times Crossword debut! This puzzle is built around a term that Mr. Sefkow coined himself and just knew he had to build a puzzle around. I love hearing the origin stories of creative themes like this one (described in more detail below), and I am particularly fond of clever portmanteaus, which, as far as I’m concerned, are the height of wit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: The Rich Got Considerably Richer
description: The Dodgers needed a starting pitcher, and they got a great one in Max Scherzer. That they added Trea Turner, a superstar infielder, in the same trade hardly seems fair.
content: LOS ANGELES — Though it was impossible to see October from the on-deck circle at the All-Star Game in Denver, the future of the Los Angeles Dodgers ever so briefly met the present on that July evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The Unlikely Issue Shaping the Virginia Governor’s Race: Schools
description: Virginia Republicans in a tight governor’s race have been staging “Parents Matter” rallies and tapping into conservative anger over mandates and critical race theory.
content: WINCHESTER, Va. — As a lifelong Republican in her home state of Virginia, Tammy Yoder faithfully casts her ballot for those who want to lower taxes, oppose abortion and back other conservative causes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: At Bessie Awards, Dancers Gather to Celebrate Pandemic Art
description: The annual awards show recognized performers across a variety of genres, including hip-hop and flamenco.
content: The pandemic brought much of the performing arts world in New York to a halt starting last year. But it could not stop dancers from pursuing their passion: at home, in parks, on rooftops and on street corners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Should Passengers Be Vaccinated or Tested to Fly Within the U.S.?
description: Numerous airline executives say no, but a growing number of politicians and medical experts say it is worth following Canada’s lead before holiday travel commences.
content: By the holiday season, flying will have changed dramatically for Americans returning to the United States from abroad. They will be asked to show proof that they are vaccinated, to commit to two coronavirus tests if they are not and to participate in a new contact tracing system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Convergence: Courage in a Crisis’ Review: Tracing a Pandemic’s Arc
description: This Netflix documentary, filmed in different countries throughout 2020, is grueling to watch.
content: A sweeping chronicle of the global fight against the coronavirus, “Convergence: Courage in a Crisis,” directed by Orlando von Einsiedel, feels too much like we’re sitting down to watch the pandemic unfold all over again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Hundreds of Police Officers Have Died From Covid. Vaccines Remain a Hard Sell.
description: Far more law enforcement officers in the U.S. have died from Covid-19 than from any other work-related cause in 2020 and 2021. Even so, police unions are fighting vaccine mandates.
content: BAKER, La. — Over the last year and a half, a majority of the roughly 40 police officers who patrol Baker, La., a suburb of Baton Rouge, tested positive for the coronavirus. All of them recovered and went back to work — until Lt. DeMarcus Dunn got sick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola and Jonathan Abrams
title: Nets Bar Kyrie Irving From All Games Until He’s Vaccinated
description: The barring of Irving complicates what looked like a surefire path to the finals for the Nets and could set up a battle with the players’ union.
content: Kyrie Irving was supposed to be the starting point guard of the N.B.A.’s next dynasty. He was going to use his superb ball-handling skills to dish passes to Kevin Durant and James Harden, and together this Big Three would turn the Nets into champions season after season for years to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Zen and the Art of Printer Maintenance
description: In her novel “LaserWriter II,” Tamara Shopsin visits the free-spirited world of Tekserve, a beloved Mac repair shop in 1990s Manhattan.
content: LASERWRITER IIBy Tamara Shopsin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Eric Schmitt
title: Iraq Says It Arrested a Leading Islamic State Figure
description: One of the most senior ISIS leaders ever to be taken alive is now reported to be in custody. The U.S. had offered a reward of up to $5 million for his capture.
content: BAGHDAD — Iraq says it has captured the Islamic State’s finance chief, a rare arrest of a major ISIS figure that could produce significant intelligence gains against the group as it struggles to re-emerge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What You’ve Missed in the Theranos Trial of Elizabeth Holmes
description: The former Silicon Valley darling faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted.
content: Unlike the frenzy that has surrounded nearly every twist and turn in the Theranos saga, the trial of Elizabeth Holmes has been surprisingly mellow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ethan Hauser and Azi Paybarah
title: The governor of Texas bars Covid vaccine mandates.
description: Gov. Greg Abbott’s latest executive order includes private employers, which had been exempt from previous edicts against mandates.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas issued a broad executive order on Monday that bars virtually any coronavirus vaccine mandate in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: More E-Scooters, More E-Bikes and More Safety Concerns
description: A surge in electric-powered mobility devices during the pandemic is likely to last.
content: It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at how e-scooters and e-bikes have changed the streetscape in New York and raised safety concerns. Scroll down and we’ll look at a professor who won a $1 million prize for real-world projects, including an algorithm to predict manhole explosions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Risk of high inflation dogs central bankers as consumer expectations climb.
description: A survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York shows inflation expectations are the highest since 2013, adding pressure for Fed officials.
content: A key measure of inflation expectations released on Tuesday showed continued acceleration, a survey that came as Richard H. Clarida, the Federal Reserve’s vice chair, indicated that central bankers were alert to the risk of high inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Steven Erlanger
title: Britain Escalates Dispute With E.U. Over Northern Ireland
description: Britain’s Brexit minister is demanding an overhaul of an agreement on trade rules for Northern Ireland.
content: LONDON — Britain set itself on course for a new confrontation with the European Union on Tuesday by demanding the replacement of one of the most complex and vexing components of Brexit: the status of Northern Ireland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Junot Díaz
title: He Read All 27,000 Marvel Comic Books and Lived to Tell the Tale
description: In “All of the Marvels,” Douglas Wolk went down a very deep rabbit hole to find the essence of what he calls the “epic of epics.”
content: ALL OF THE MARVELSA Journey to the Ends of the Biggest Story Ever ToldBy Douglas Wolk
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Joy Dong
title: In China, Home Buyers Who Went All In Say They Want Out
description: China Evergrande Group’s financial troubles, and the government policies that helped push it to the brink of collapse, have threatened an important economic driver: home sales.
content: China is trying to cool its costly and dangerously debt-ridden housing market, where high prices and go-go levels of borrowing and spending are increasingly seen as a national threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Sally Rooney Declines to Sell Translation Rights to Israeli Publisher
description: The author of “Beautiful World, Where Are You” turned down an offer from an Israeli publisher to translate the novel to Hebrew, citing her support for Palestinians “in their struggle for freedom, justice and equality.”
content: The Irish novelist Sally Rooney said on Tuesday that she would not allow the Israeli publishing house that handled her previous novels to publish her most recent book, “Beautiful World, Where Are You,” because of her support for Palestinian people and the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Beanie Feldstein Feels It All in ‘Impeachment’
description: The actor spends most of Tuesday’s episode in tears or hysterics as the show recreates Monica Lewinsky’s detainment by the F.B.I. “I don’t know if I’ll ever get over it,” Feldstein said.
content: Beanie Feldstein is allergic to nearly everything — cats, dairy, fragrances, dust. “I basically live in a bubble,” she said. The sticks and sprays that help actors to cry on cue? She is allergic to those, too. So earlier this year, shooting 16-hour days on a set made to look like a Ritz-Carlton suite, she made herself cry in take after take, with no artificial tears to help her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Sameer Yasir
title: ‘Are We Human?’ Modi’s Use of Antiterror Law Draws Scrutiny From Courts
description: India’s government under Prime Minister Narendra Modi has jailed thousands of people through a statute that critics say is aimed at silencing dissent.
content: NEW DELHI — The two women walked through the gate of India’s notorious Tihar prison raising their fists and chanting protest slogans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Natural immunity vs. vaccines.
content: As vaccine mandates roll out, a national debate has been brewing about whether the rules should apply to those who have so-called natural immunity from a previous coronavirus infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How an 11-Foot-Tall 3-D Printer Is Helping to Create a Community’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how 3-D printing technology is being used to build new homes. Then, they will propose ways to use the cutting-edge technology to address a social need in their own community.
content: Featured Article: “How an 11-Foot-Tall 3-D Printer Is Helping to Create a Community” by Debra Kamin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: The New Jersey’s governor’s race puts mandates to a political test.
description: New Jersey’s governor’s race, which is one of just two governor’s races in the country before next year’s midterm elections, is seen by some as an early barometer of voter sentiment.
content: New Jersey’s governor’s race, which is one of just two governor’s races in the country before next year’s midterm elections, is seen by some as an early barometer of voter sentiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Old Glory
description: Should the American Flag be redesigned?
content: For nearly 250 years, the American flag has been made and remade.  A recent Times article showcased several new updates to the flag, as imagined by six artists and graphic designers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: American and Southwest Airlines reject the Texas order banning vaccine mandates.
description: “This does not change anything for American,” a spokeswoman said. When the airline introduced its mandate, it cited a presidential order that employees of government contractors be vaccinated.
content: American Airlines and Southwest Airlines, citing federal requirements, said on Tuesday that they would not comply with an order from the governor of Texas barring private employers from mandating coronavirus vaccines in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Trump’s Shadow Looms as Lev Parnas Trial Begins in New York
description: Though Mr. Parnas played a key role in the events that led to the former president’s impeachment, the charges he faces involve accusations of campaign finance violations.
content: For Lev Parnas, a Ukrainian American businessman living in Florida, 2018 was a busy year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Red Sox Ride a Wave of Offense Into the A.L.C.S.
description: It sometimes feels like the Tampa Bay Rays are reinventing baseball, but it was Boston that upended conventional wisdom by using good hitting to beat good pitching in October.
content: BOSTON — So this was how it ended for the Tampa Bay Rays, the team that pushes and pokes conventional thinking and usually gets away with it. The Rays set a franchise record with 100 victories this season, eight more than the Boston Red Sox. But when it mattered most, in their American League division series, the Red Sox upended the hoariest axiom of all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Lauren Keiles
title: A Brief Introduction to Philosophy (Through a Certain Sex Act)
description: For the comedian Jacqueline Novak, the embarrassing and uncomfortable are a gateway to the profound.
content: It was a Monday night in August at the Bell House in Brooklyn, and Jacqueline Novak was sneaking in a few more dates of her hit one-woman show, “Get On Your Knees.” The 80-minute standup spectacle — which she sometimes must describe, for marketing reasons, as “a highbrow show about blowjobs” — had just ended its second run Off Broadway. A few days later, it would depart on tour. The crowd that night was girls and gays, plus a handful of older Manhattan-types with an air of having read about the show. They’d come for “provocative and superbly articulate material” (The Hollywood Reporter); an “overthinker’s delight” (The New Yorker); “a one-woman oral-sex meditation that’s part-standup, part-poetic treatise” (Vanity Fair).
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Nick Offerman
description: A conversation with the actor and author
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Nick Offerman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Past Pandemics Remind Us Covid Will Be an Era, Not a Crisis That Fades
description: History repeatedly demonstrates how difficult it is to decisively declare that a pandemic is over.
content: The skeletons move across a barren landscape toward the few helpless and terrified people still living. The scene, imagined in a mid-16th-century painting, “The Triumph of Death” by Pieter Bruegel the Elder, illuminated the psychic impact of the bubonic plague.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Letters of Suresh’ Review: Returning to the Fold
description: Rajiv Joseph’s new drama revisits the protagonist, and the metaphoric possibilities of origami, of his earlier play “Animals Out of Paper.”
content: We live in the age of the reboot: an era of reimaginings, spinoffs and sequels upon sequels upon sequels. Theater, with its dependence on adaptation and revival, got there first. But this impulse now extends to new plays, too — “A Doll’s House, Part 2,” Zoom installments of the Apple Family Plays, the way that “Pass Over” riffs on “Waiting for Godot.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Cecily Strong to Make New York Theater Debut at the Shed
description: The “S.N.L.” star steps into a role originated by Lily Tomlin, and Claudia Rankine’s “Help” gets its pandemic-delayed world premiere in the new Shed season.
content: Cecily Strong has twice been nominated for an Emmy Award for her standout “Saturday Night Live” impressions that have included Melania Trump, Ariana Grande and Lin-Manuel Miranda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Rise of a Far-Right Pundit Is Scrambling French Politics
description: Éric Zemmour, an anti-immigrant writer and TV commentator, is surging in opinion polls before presidential elections next year — and he is not yet a candidate.
content: PARIS — He is the anti-immigration son of parents from Algeria. He styles himself as the great defender of France’s Christian civilization, though he himself is Jewish. He channels Donald J. Trump in an anti-establishment campaign. And he is now scrambling the battle lines before France’s presidential election in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Temporary Concert Hall Hopes for a Permanent Audience
description: The Isarphilharmonie in Munich, a prefabricated stopgap during a renovation, is trying to lure listeners far from the city center.
content: MUNICH — It was an unusual sight last Friday: the denizens of this wealthy city lifting the hems of their gowns and adjusting their bow ties as they stepped into a rough-around-the-edges industrial space for one of the premier cultural events of the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: As Big Tech Grows in the Pandemic, Seattle Grows With It
description: Despite an overall decline in office leasing in the United States, technology companies gobbled up more space in the Seattle area than they had the previous year.
content: The pandemic was a disaster for commercial real estate markets. In the Seattle area, it was a boon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Muses on Trump’s Weekend Iowa Rally
description: The host said that seeing the former president speak was like “watching an open-mic night at the senior center.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: National Issues Dominate Ad Wars in Virginia Governor’s Race
description: In a governor’s race deemed a bellwether for the 2022 midterms, the battle between Terry McAuliffe and Glenn Youngkin has ignited over national cultural issues.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: Why ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ the Album Has Always Rocked
description: When I discovered the record, it felt like the bizarre offspring of my deepest, dorkiest passions: theater and dad rock.
content: I’m here to spread the good word of “Jesus Christ Superstar,” the album.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: What Does a University Owe Democracy?
description: Academia can still serve the goals of liberty. But first the Coward Culture has to go.
content: Last November, Dorian Abbot, a geophysicist at the University of Chicago, posted a series of slide presentations on YouTube making a case against the use of group identity as a primary criterion in selection processes. He was immediately targeted for cancellation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: ‘Dopesick’ Depicts the Opioid Crisis From All Sides
description: A Hulu mini-series traces the story of OxyContin from the offices of Purdue Pharma to the examining room of an Appalachian doctor (played by Michael Keaton).
content: “Dopesick,” Hulu’s ambitious and intermittently compelling mini-series about the role of Purdue Pharma in the opioid crisis, is built around the theme of pain. Nearly every significant character, whether or not they’re taking Purdue’s best-selling drug OxyContin, is suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and Julian E. Barnes
title: Maryland Couple Accused of Selling Submarine Secrets Appear in Court
description: Jonathan and Diana Toebbe face life in prison if convicted on the charges. Prosecutors, saying they are flight risks, are seeking to keep them in detention.
content: MARTINSBURG, W.Va. — The Maryland couple accused of trying to sell some of America’s most closely guarded nuclear submarine secrets made their first appearance in court since they were arrested over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Why a Sea Dispute Has Somalia and Kenya on Edge
description: A court ruling largely gave Somalia control over a patch of the Indian Ocean believed to be rich in oil and gas, a decision that may further raise tensions between the countries.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — The United Nations’ top court largely sided with Somalia over Kenya on Tuesday in a dispute over how to demarcate a disputed area in the Indian Ocean thought to be rich in oil and gas, a major decision that could escalate tensions in the region and ultimately reshape the two countries’ maritime borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Countries around the globe turn to vaccine mandates to fight coronavirus.
description: The number of activities available to the unvaccinated is shrinking, and the pressure to get shots is growing.
content: In their struggle to convince holdouts to get vaccinated against Covid, governments around the world are embracing vaccine mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Jon Gruden’s Departure Means More Trouble for the Raiders
description: The Raiders moved to a new, $2 billion stadium in Las Vegas last year, hoping to build a football dynasty. Things haven’t gone as they’d hoped.
content: On the lower level of Allegiant Stadium on Sunday, Raiders running back Josh Jacobs defended his team, which had just lost sloppily, 20-9, to the Chicago Bears only two days after reports that Coach Jon Gruden used a racist stereotype in reference to DeMaurice Smith, a Black man and the executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan and Josh Robenstone
title: In Shanghai, Teahouses Offer Both Community and Solitude

title: Henry Louis Gates Jr. on Literary Freedom as an Essential Human Right

content: “The freedom to write”: PEN America’s always resonant motto has a special resonance for Black authors, because for so many of them, that freedom was one they fought hard for. “Liberation” and “literacy” were inextricable. “For the horrors of the American Negro’s life there has been almost no language,” as James Baldwin once noted. Recall, first, that in many states it was illegal for an enslaved person even to learn how to read and how to write. Then the barbarities of the slave trade, the Middle Passage and cradle-to-grave bondage, were followed by another century of lynching, Jim Crow segregation, disenfranchisement and officially sanctioned forms of violence. Does the English language fail us, Baldwin wonders, in the face of racist terror? No, he decides; we must embrace it, occupy it, refashion it in our images, speak it in our own voices. We must deploy it to redress this terror. “To accept one’s past — one’s history,” as Baldwin insisted, “is not the same as drowning with it; it is learning how to use it.” This, surely, is integral to the freedom to write — the freedom to bear witness to the full range of our common humanity, and all that that entails, no matter how uncomfortable the process can be.

content: Most Saturday nights from age 5 to 10, Ahmir Thompson would go to bed at 8 p.m., only to be woken up a few hours later. When he was 3, he had taken a fruit-drink commercial too literally — “Hey, how about a nice Hawaiian punch?” ended with a fist to his mother’s face — so his parents decided to limit his television consumption. But on the weekends, they bent the rules and, around 12:45 a.m., nudged him awake. He would grab his crocheted-by-Grandma blanket and head downstairs, where he would switch on the television, wait for it to warm up and then crank the dial to Channel 48 as quietly as he could. Right at 1 a.m., he was greeted by a magical locomotive — chugging along so rhythmically that it almost seemed to dance, flipping gray buildings it passed into psychedelic colors — for his regular dose of peace, love and “Soul Train.”

It’s named for Robert Whittle Dowling, a former owner of the hotel and an influential urban planner. The room has shed the somewhat fussy country house décor of its previous iteration as the Carlyle Restaurant in favor of a sleeker 1940s look in black, white, silver and lime, more supper club than dining room. The walls are covered with photos, graphics and paintings, many of them vintage, including the Bemelmans prints. There’s also a new chef in charge, Sylvain Delpique, formerly of the “21” Club, whose menu is stylishly conservative, befitting the Upper East Side, with foie gras terrine, tuna tartare, a wedge salad, roast chicken and, given tableside flourish, Dover sole and steak Diane. Béarnaise sauce replaces ketchup or mayo for dipping the waffle fries. His excellent chicken paillard from “21” is also on the menu. “I’ve brought over a few dishes, things I like to prepare,” he said. The walls of a cozy bar, a prelude to the restaurant, are sheathed in bright, glossy tortoise shell pattern. (Opens Tuesday)

content: Six weeks after announcing that grade-school students in New Jersey would again need to wear masks in class, Gov. Philip D. Murphy, a Democrat, issued a new executive order, his 264th: Children 2 and older in day care centers would also have to wear face coverings.

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Players on N.H.L.’s newest team are sidelined by Covid protocols before debut.
description: The Seattle Kraken was set to play its first-ever regular-season National Hockey League game on Tuesday against the Vegas Golden Nights
content: The Seattle Kraken have yet to play a game in the National Hockey League. On the eve of their debut, five players have already been sidelined by an implacable foe: the league’s Covid-19 protocols.

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The N.F.L.’s Hypocrisy Was on Full Display in Gruden’s Emails
description: As the league is trying to send a signal about inclusion and diversity, hate-filled correspondence between football power brokers reveals entrenched values.
content: Jon Gruden’s resignation from the Las Vegas Raiders, after stunning revelations about his history of racist, misogynistic and homophobic emails, points to a deep truth about the National Football League: The league can write as many antiracism slogans in end zones and add as many rainbows to its social media accounts as it wants, but its hypocrisy is evident in the actions of its decision makers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Designer Who Finds Beauty in Decay
description: In a Warsaw warehouse, Marcin Rusak turns decomposing plant material into polished pieces that degrade over time.
content: ONE OF THE designer Marcin Rusak’s lasting memories from his childhood in Poland was spending time in his family’s greenhouses. His maternal great-grandfather and grandfather were flower growers in Warsaw and, although their business shuttered just before he was born, he often played in those abandoned, overgrown glass structures. “I can still feel the warmth and smell the weeds and bacteria growing there,” he says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: If You’ve Had Covid, Do You Need the Vaccine?
description: So-called natural immunity varies from patient to patient, scientists say. Immunization is still the best choice after recovering from the disease.
content: When Jonathan Isaac, a prominent basketball player for the Orlando Magic, explained why he chose not to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, he tapped into a dispute that has been simmering for months: Do people who have had Covid-19, as Mr. Isaac said he has, really need the vaccine?

content: Seven nights a week, starting around 9:30, Vincent Carrasco cheers and whistles at food delivery workers as they ride their bicycles into Manhattan after crossing the Queensboro Bridge. The message he’s sending? “Someone’s looking out for you.”

title: Covid and Age
description: An unvaccinated child is at less risk of serious Covid illness than a vaccinated 70-year-old.
content: Emily Oster, an economist at Brown University who frequently writes about parenting, published an article in The Atlantic in March that made a lot of people angry. The headline was, “Your Unvaccinated Kid Is Like a Vaccinated Grandma.” The article argued that Covid-19 tended to be so mild in children that vaccinated parents could feel comfortable going out in the world with their unvaccinated children.

title: Temple Bar, a Moody Enclave for Martinis, Is Set to Reopen

content: Temple Bar, the clandestine bar on Lafayette Street that served up martinis, mood lighting and a downtown version of uptown glamour until it closed on New Year’s Eve in 2017, will reopen Thursday. And though the management may be new, it is decidedly loyal to the memory of the original.

author: By Jonathan Lee
title: The Park Bench Is an Endangered Species
description: In a world that wants you to pay for everything, public seating is becoming a luxury.
content: As a kid growing up in a gray suburb of London, I loved to go looking for the perfect park bench. We had only five in our local park, and one was broken. Some Sunday mornings, my dad could be persuaded to drive to new parks. We’d have a kick-around with a soccer ball, share a bag of Doritos and check out all the benches in the area, reading their dedications, inscriptions and graffiti.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘An Idyllic Trip to Salvage Our Romance’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: There’s a stretch of Highway 17 that runs from Hardeeville, S.C., to Charleston, where raspberry-colored azalea bushes dot the road in spring, peach jam and boiled peanuts sit in stands in late summer, and Gullah artisans sell their sweetgrass baskets year-round. This span of highway also marks the geographical distance in my marriage. To bridge the expanse, Mike sends me early-morning emails; he has done this every day since we met nine years ago. When I read his messages, I think of us: Two people, two hours apart, awakening for the same love. — Deborah J. Cohan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Play Drunk
description: It’s one of the hardest feats of performance. Find the right balance between subtlety and audience expectations.
content: “Acting drunk convincingly is about the hardest thing you can do,” says D.W. Brown, 60, an acting coach based in Santa Monica, Calif., who has worked with both film and stage actors. There are famous film scenes for which actors are said to have drunk alcohol, but getting intoxicated for real is ill advised, especially for stage actors, who perform the same scene day after day. Figure out how to fake it instead, which will require practiced motor-skill impairment and discernible psychological shifts.
